sentence: TMEM97 has the highest expression in luminal B tumors (Fig. 1A).
In an analogous manner, PGRMC1 was expressed at higher levels in ER− tumors, PR− tumors, and ER−/HER2− tumors (Fig. 1B).
PGRMC1 was also expressed at higher levels in tumors of higher grade (P = 2.5 × 10−14) and smaller size (P = 4.7 × 10−7; Fig. 1C).

In the integrated dataset, LDLR and TMEM97 also had the highest expression in ER− disease (P = 4.7e−14 and P = 0.041, respectively; Fig. 1B); LDLR and TMEM97 were also each expressed at higher levels in tumors of higher grade (P = 1.1 × 10−08 and 6.1 × 10−64, respectively; Fig. 1C).

The results demonstrated that PGRMC1 expression is associated with a higher risk of early relapse (within 5 years) across all patients with breast cancer [HR = 1.25; 95% confidence interval (CI) = 1.12–1.39; P = 6.4 × 10−5; Fig. 2A].
Within the basal subtype, PGRMC1 expression was also associated with relapse (HR = 1.29; 95% CI = 1.04–1.60; P = 0.018; Fig. 2B).

The risk of early recurrence with TMEM97 was present only in ER+/HER2− disease (HR = 1.5; 95% CI = 1.35–1.67; P = 5.4−14) and ER+ malignancies (HR = 1.49; 95% CI = 1.31–1.68; P = 3.1−10) and was not present in ER−/HER2− (HR = 1.05; 95% CI = 0.88–1.25; P = 0.63) or ER− disease (HR = 1.02; 95% CI = 0.89–1.17; P = 0.75; Fig. 3A and B).
The CIs for PAM50, Oncotype DX, and our new proliferation signature were from 0.63 to 0.66, which is moderate and reasonable, consistent with these prior reported data (Fig. 4).
The CIs for PAM50, Oncotype DX, and our new proliferation signature were from 0.63 to 0.66, which is moderate and reasonable, consistent with these prior reported data (Fig. 4).
This is when the sigma-2–PGRMC1–LDL complex becomes crucial, as it can enhance the rate of internalization by up to tenfold (Fig. 5).
